ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Worksheets and news videos with which to prepare and to watch asynchronously

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot of formal Chinese vocabulary and how to read and write Chinese news articles.
Learned how to discuss current events/issues at a high level in Mandarin

I learned how to write and read Chinese news articles. I learned a lot of new vocabulary and how to discuss a series of current events about China including the gay rights movement, earthquakes, social media, diplomacy, film releases, art auctions, etc.
Overall, I increased my fluency in Chinese and learned to read Newspaper articles and digest the information
Constant and consistent hard work is key, especially in language learning

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: this class gives you a lot control over learning whatever Chinese vocabulary you want to learn. Weaknesses: Because this class isn't as structured as other Chinese classes, you only get out of this class as much as you put into it. You can probably get by without doing all of the assigned readings, but you won't learn as much from the class then.

The zoom format is just not very conducive to developing verbal and language skills, it is hard to pay attention for such an extended period of time  over zoom while conversing in another language.

Course was very good at developing reading skills.

Zhou Laoshi is just one of the best Chinese professors at Yale, and he is easily the highlight of the course. The workload is not too much, essays and oral presentations every other week, short multi-sentence news articles weekly, and self-made quizlets for every new group of articles. The articles are pretty interesting, too. Weaknesses include sometimes it was hard to speak with 12 people in the class (though, that is average for most Chinese classes at Yale)smaller class sizes might benefit. Another weakness is that it's somewhat easy to not do all of the readings, though it's important to for familiarity and language practice. The discussions turned into people saying what interested them most about the readings. Zhou Laoshi did a good job of encouraging us  to actually discuss and build off of each others points, but because not everyone always does the same readings sometimes that's hard to ensure.
there was a lot of consistent work, but i actually found that to be really helpful in keeping things in check!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the quizlet assignments and also being able to see what Chinese vocabulary my other classmates were studying; however, I thought that some of the lectures were dry. It would be nice if there were more opportunities to speak with classmates and practice the vocabulary that we've been learning.
I think the reading and homework was very well-suited for virtual learning, as were some of the media assignments and components, like when we watched news videos and movies.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are hoping to improve your Chinese writing ability and reading comprehension in a more formal setting, then I would recommend this course. If you are hoping to improve your Chinese speaking ability and listening comprehension, then this course might not be for you.
It would depend on whether the format is in person or over zoom. If in person then probably yes, but over zoom no.
Yes, any Chinese class with Zhou Laoshi is an excellent course. The units change a lot so it stays interesting, and it's a good way to talk and read about a bunch of different topics in Chinese.

I would reccomend it. Workload is not too bad and learning to read Chinese news articles is an extremely valuable skill. This class is structured so you definitely can get as much out of it as you put in.
Yes, Zhou laoshi is really prompt in answering emails and provides excellent feedback with regards to all aspect of coursework (written assignments, presentations, group projects, final projects etc)
